description: Foundational mathematics: Number systems, basic operations, and fundamental concepts

definition.text: Natural numbers are the counting numbers starting from 1 (or 0 in some definitions). They are denoted by ℕ and include {1, 2, 3, 4, ...}. Natural numbers are used for counting and ordering.

keyFormulas.name: Closure Properties
keyFormulas.formula: a + b ∈ ℕ and a × b ∈ ℕ for all a, b ∈ ℕ
keyFormulas.meaning: Sum and product of natural numbers is natural

keyFormulas.name: Sum of First n Natural Numbers

examples.question: Find the sum of first 100 natural numbers
examples.verification: Gauss famously solved this as a child

proof: Write S again in reverse: S = n + (n-1) + ... + 1
Add both equations: 2S = (1+n) + (2+n-1) + ... + (n+1)
Each pair sums to (n+1), and there are n pairs

realWorldApplications.title: Counting
realWorldApplications.description: Basic counting of objects, people, items

definition.text: Integers include all whole numbers, both positive and negative, plus zero. Denoted by ℤ (from German 'Zahlen'), integers are {..., -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, ...}. They allow subtraction to always produce a result.

keyFormulas.name: Absolute Value
keyFormulas.meaning: Distance from zero on number line

steps.action: Apply sign rule: negative × negative = positive

definition.text: A fraction represents a part of a whole, written as a/b where 'a' is the numerator and 'b' is the denominator (b ≠ 0). Fractions can be converted to decimals by division. Equivalent fractions represent the same value.

steps.explanation: Flip the second fraction and multiply

definition.text: An exponent indicates how many times a number (the base) is multiplied by itself. In aⁿ, 'a' is the base and 'n' is the exponent. A radical (√) represents roots - the inverse operation of exponentiation.

keyFormulas.name: Zero Exponent
keyFormulas.meaning: Any non-zero number to power 0 is 1

steps.action: Apply product rule: same base, add exponents
Factor 50 into perfect square and remainder

steps.explanation: Can do root then power, or power then root

realWorldApplications.title: Compound Interest
realWorldApplications.description: A = P(1 + r)ⁿ for interest calculations

definition.text: The order of operations is a set of rules for evaluating mathematical expressions. PEMDAS (or BODMAS) ensures everyone gets the same answer: Parentheses, Exponents, Multiplication/Division (left to right), Addition/Subtraction (left to right).

keyFormulas.name: Left to Right Rule
keyFormulas.formula: Same precedence: work left to right
keyFormulas.meaning: Multiply and divide in order; add and subtract in order

steps.action: Start with innermost parentheses - do exponent first
Division and multiplication have same precedence
steps.explanation: Same level, go left to right

realWorldApplications.title: Spreadsheets
realWorldApplications.description: Excel and Google Sheets follow order of operations

realWorldApplications.title: Programming
realWorldApplications.description: All programming languages use operator precedence

definition.text: Rational numbers are numbers that can be expressed as a ratio p/q where p and q are integers and q ≠ 0. The set is denoted by ℚ (from 'quotient'). Every rational number has a decimal representation that either terminates or repeats.

keyFormulas.name: Rational Number Set
keyFormulas.meaning: Set of all ratios of integers

keyFormulas.name: Density Property
keyFormulas.formula: Between any two rationals, there exists another rational
keyFormulas.meaning: Rationals are dense on the number line

steps.action: Assume √2 = p/q where p,q are integers with no common factors
If p² is even, then p is even

steps.explanation: This means q is also even

steps.result: Both p and q are even, but we assumed no common factors

realWorldApplications.title: Measurements
realWorldApplications.description: Most real-world measurements can be expressed as rationals

definition.text: Irrational numbers are real numbers that cannot be expressed as a ratio of integers. Their decimal expansions are non-terminating and non-repeating. Famous examples include π, e, √2, and the golden ratio φ.

keyFormulas.name: Golden Ratio (φ)
keyFormulas.meaning: The golden ratio, appears in nature

keyFormulas.name: Square Root of Non-Perfect Squares
keyFormulas.formula: √n is irrational if n is not a perfect square

proof: This was first proven by Johann Lambert in 1761
A simpler proof by Ivan Niven (1947) uses calculus
The proof shows that assuming π = p/q leads to a contradiction
The full proof requires advanced calculus concepts

realWorldApplications.title: Circles
realWorldApplications.description: π appears in all circle calculations

realWorldApplications.title: Nature
realWorldApplications.description: Golden ratio φ in spirals, flowers, galaxies

realWorldApplications.title: Compound Growth
realWorldApplications.description: e appears in continuous growth formulas

definition.text: Real numbers include all rational and irrational numbers. They can be represented as points on an infinite number line. The set ℝ is complete, meaning there are no 'gaps' - every Cauchy sequence converges to a real number.

steps.explanation: Square bracket for included, parenthesis for excluded

realWorldApplications.title: Physics
realWorldApplications.description: All physical measurements are real numbers

realWorldApplications.title: Temperature
realWorldApplications.description: Temperature scales use the real number line

realWorldApplications.title: Time
realWorldApplications.description: Continuous time is modeled by real numbers

definition.text: Complex numbers extend the real numbers by including the imaginary unit i, where i² = -1. Every complex number can be written as a + bi, where a is the real part and b is the imaginary part. They complete algebra by ensuring every polynomial has roots.

keyFormulas.name: Euler's Formula
keyFormulas.formula: e^(iθ) = cos θ + i sin θ

examples.question: Simplify i³
examples.verification: Pattern: i¹=i, i²=-1, i³=-i, i⁴=1, then repeats

proof: Every non-constant polynomial with complex coefficients has at least one complex root
This means every polynomial of degree n has exactly n roots (counting multiplicity)
The proof requires advanced analysis (not elementary)
This is why ℂ is called 'algebraically closed'

definition.text: A percentage is a number expressed as a fraction of 100, denoted by the symbol %. 'Percent' means 'per hundred'. Percentages are used to express ratios, proportions, changes, and comparisons in an easily understood format.

keyFormulas.name: Percentage Of
keyFormulas.meaning: Finding a percentage of a number

examples.question: A shirt costs $40 and is on sale for 30% off. What is the sale price?
If a stock price rises from $50 to $62, what is the percentage increase?

definition.text: Place value is the value of a digit based on its position in a number. In our base-10 system, each position represents a power of 10. Understanding place value is fundamental to reading, writing, and comparing numbers.

keyFormulas.name: Place Value Positions
keyFormulas.formula: ...millions, hundred-thousands, ten-thousands, thousands, hundreds, tens, ones
keyFormulas.meaning: Each position is 10× the position to its right

keyFormulas.name: Expanded Form
keyFormulas.meaning: Breaking a number into place values

examples.question: What is the value of 7 in 47,285?

steps.explanation: Count from right: ones, tens, hundreds, thousands
Multiply each digit by its place value

definition.text: Rounding replaces a number with an approximate value that has fewer significant digits. Estimation uses rounding to quickly calculate approximate answers. These skills help verify calculations and make mental math easier.

keyFormulas.name: Rounding Rule
keyFormulas.formula: If digit ≥ 5, round up; if digit < 5, round down

keyFormulas.name: Rounding Decimals
keyFormulas.formula: Look at digit after target place to decide

steps.action: Look at digit to the right
Round each number to nearest ten

definition.text: A factor of a number divides it evenly with no remainder. A multiple of a number is the product of that number and any whole number. Understanding factors and multiples is essential for working with fractions and algebra.

keyFormulas.name: Factor Definition
keyFormulas.formula: a is a factor of b if b ÷ a has no remainder
keyFormulas.latex: a | b \text{ means } b = a \times k \text{ for some integer } k

keyFormulas.name: Multiple Definition
keyFormulas.meaning: Products of n with counting numbers

realWorldApplications.title: Scheduling
realWorldApplications.description: Events that repeat at regular intervals

definition.text: The Greatest Common Divisor (GCD) is the largest number that divides two numbers evenly. The Least Common Multiple (LCM) is the smallest number that is a multiple of both numbers. These are essential for simplifying fractions and adding fractions.

keyFormulas.name: GCD Using Prime Factorization
keyFormulas.formula: GCD = product of common primes with smallest powers
keyFormulas.meaning: Take minimum exponents of shared primes

keyFormulas.name: LCM Using Prime Factorization
keyFormulas.formula: LCM = product of all primes with largest powers
keyFormulas.meaning: Take maximum exponents of all primes

steps.action: Take minimum powers of common primes
Take maximum powers of all primes

examples.question: Two buses leave a station. One returns every 15 min, the other every 20 min. When will they both be at the station again?

steps.explanation: First time both cycles complete together

examples.finalAnswer: Both buses will be at the station in 60 minutes

realWorldApplications.title: Simplifying Fractions
realWorldApplications.description: GCD helps reduce fractions to lowest terms

realWorldApplications.title: Scheduling
realWorldApplications.description: When events with different periods coincide

definition.text: A ratio compares two quantities using division. A proportion states that two ratios are equal. Proportional reasoning is fundamental to scaling, similarity, percentages, and real-world problem solving.

keyFormulas.name: Ratio Notation
keyFormulas.formula: a:b or a/b or 'a to b'
keyFormulas.meaning: Three ways to write the same ratio

keyFormulas.name: Cross Multiplication
keyFormulas.formula: If a/b = c/d, then ad = bc

keyFormulas.name: Unit Rate
keyFormulas.formula: Rate per one unit = total ÷ quantity

examples.question: If the ratio of boys to girls is 3:5 and there are 24 students total, how many are boys?
A car travels 240 miles in 4 hours. What is the unit rate (speed)?

definition.text: A prime number is a natural number greater than 1 that has exactly two factors: 1 and itself. The Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic states every integer > 1 can be expressed as a unique product of primes.

keyFormulas.name: Prime Definition
keyFormulas.formula: p is prime if its only factors are 1 and p

steps.explanation: 45 is odd, can't divide by 2 more

proofOfConcept.theorem: There are infinitely many primes (Euclid's proof)
proof: Assume there are finitely many primes: p₁, p₂, ..., pₙ
Consider N = p₁ × p₂ × ... × pₙ + 1
N is not divisible by any of our primes (remainder 1)
So N is either prime, or has a prime factor not in our list
Either way, we found a new prime - contradiction!
Therefore, there must be infinitely many primes □

definition.text: The four basic operations are addition (+), subtraction (−), multiplication (×), and division (÷). These operations follow specific properties like commutativity, associativity, and distributivity that make calculations easier.

keyFormulas.name: Commutative Property
keyFormulas.formula: a + b = b + a, a × b = b × a
keyFormulas.latex: a + b = b + a, \quad a \times b = b \times a

keyFormulas.name: Distributive Property
keyFormulas.formula: a × (b + c) = a × b + a × c

keyFormulas.name: Identity Properties
keyFormulas.meaning: 0 is additive identity, 1 is multiplicative identity

definition.text: Scientific notation expresses numbers as a product of a coefficient (1 ≤ |a| < 10) and a power of 10. It's used for very large or very small numbers in science and engineering.

Decimals represent fractional parts using place value to the right of the decimal point. Operations with decimals follow the same rules as whole numbers but require careful attention to decimal placement.

keyFormulas.name: Adding/Subtracting Decimals
keyFormulas.formula: Line up decimal points, then add/subtract

keyFormulas.name: Multiplying Decimals
keyFormulas.formula: Multiply as whole numbers, count total decimal places

keyFormulas.name: Dividing Decimals
keyFormulas.formula: Move decimal in divisor to make whole, move same in dividend

examples.question: Calculate 2.5 × 0.4
examples.verification: Half of 2.5 is 1.25, so 0.4 × 2.5 should be near 1 ✓

definition.text: Number properties are fundamental rules that govern how numbers behave in operations. Understanding these properties helps simplify calculations and is essential for algebra.

keyFormulas.name: Multiplicative Identity
keyFormulas.meaning: Multiplying by 1 doesn't change a number

keyFormulas.name: Additive Inverse
keyFormulas.meaning: A number plus its opposite is 0

keyFormulas.name: Multiplicative Inverse
keyFormulas.meaning: A number times its reciprocal is 1

examples.question: Use associative property to simplify: (25 × 7) × 4
examples.verification: Grouping strategically makes mental math easier

definition.text: Signed numbers include positive and negative numbers. Operations with signed numbers follow specific rules for determining the sign of results. Negative numbers represent values less than zero.

keyFormulas.name: Adding Same Signs
keyFormulas.meaning: Same signs: add absolute values, keep sign

keyFormulas.name: Adding Different Signs
keyFormulas.meaning: Different signs: subtract, use sign of larger

examples.question: Calculate (-8) + (+3)

steps.action: Different signs, so subtract absolute values
Use sign of number with larger absolute value
steps.explanation: −8 has larger absolute value, so negative

examples.verification: On number line: start at -8, move 3 right to -5 ✓

steps.explanation: Take sign of larger absolute value

definition.text: Square numbers result from multiplying a number by itself. Cube numbers result from multiplying a number by itself three times. Perfect squares and cubes are important in algebra and geometry.
